mil3.1.1:1.1.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā yenāyasmā nāgaseno tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā nāgasenena saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mil3.1.1:1.1.eng: Then, King Milinda approached Venerable Nāgasena, exchanged cordial and polite greetings with him, and sat down at one side.

mil3.1.1:1.2.pli: Āyasmāpi kho nāgaseno paṭisammodanīyeneva milindassa rañño cittaṃ ārādhesi.
mil3.1.1:1.2.eng: Venerable Nāgasena, by returning polite greetings back, gladdened King Milinda’s heart.

mil3.1.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.1:2.1.eng: Then, King Milinda said to Venerable Nāgasena,

mil3.1.1:2.2.eng: “How is the reverend one known, what is your name, venerable sir?”

mil3.1.1:2.3.pli: “‘Nāgaseno’ti kho ahaṃ, mahārāja, ñāyāmi, ‘nāgaseno’ti kho maṃ, mahārāja, sabrahmacārī samudācaranti, api ca mātāpitaro nāmaṃ karonti ‘nāgaseno’ti vā ‘sūraseno’ti vā ‘vīraseno’ti vā ‘sīhaseno’ti vā, api ca kho, mahārāja, saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāro nāmamattaṃ yadidaṃ nāgasenoti, na hettha puggalo upalabbhatī”ti.
mil3.1.1:2.3.eng: “I am called Nāgasena, your majesty, my holy life companions address me as Nāgasena. Though parents make such names as Nāgasena, or Sūrasena, or Vīrasena, or Sīhasena, your majesty, Nāgasena is only a concept, a designation, a label, an appellation, a mere name; no person actually obtains here.”

mil3.1.1:3.2.pli: “suṇantu me bhonto pañcasatā yonakā asītisahassā ca bhikkhū, ayaṃ nāgaseno evamāha—
mil3.1.1:3.2.eng: “May the venerable five hundred Bactrian Greeks and the eighty thousand bhikkhus hear me. This Nāgasena said,

mil3.1.1:3.3.pli: ‘na hettha puggalo upalabbhatī’ti, kallaṃ nu kho tadabhinanditun”ti.
mil3.1.1:3.3.eng: ‘no person obtains here’; is it proper to approve that?”

mil3.1.1:3.4.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.1:3.4.eng: Then, King Milinda said this to Venerable Nāgasena,

mil3.1.1:3.5.pli: “sace, bhante nāgasena, puggalo nūpalabbhati, ko carahi tumhākaṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ deti, ko taṃ paribhuñjati, ko sīlaṃ rakkhati, ko bhāvanamanuyuñjati, ko maggaphalanibbānāni sacchikaroti, ko pāṇaṃ hanati, ko adinnaṃ ādiyati, ko kāmesumicchācāraṃ carati, ko musā bhaṇati, ko majjaṃ pivati, ko pañcānantariyakammaṃ karoti, tasmā natthi kusalaṃ, natthi akusalaṃ, natthi kusalākusalānaṃ kammānaṃ kattā vā kāretā vā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, sace, bhante nāgasena, yo tumhe māreti, natthi tassāpi pāṇātipāto, tumhākampi, bhante nāgasena, natthi ācariyo, natthi upajjhāyo, natthi upasampadā.
mil3.1.1:3.5.eng: “If, Venerable Nāgasena, no person obtains, who therefore gives you robes, alms food, lodgings and medicinal requisites? Who enjoys the use of them? Who guards their ethical behaviour? Who engages in meditation? Who attains the path and fruit of nibbāna? Who kills a living being? Who takes what is not given? Who commits wrong conduct in sensual pleasures? Who speaks falsely? Who drinks intoxicants? Who commits any of the five deeds that bear fruit without delay? Therefore, there is nothing wholesome, nothing unwholesome. There is no doer of wholesome and unwholesome deeds, nor anyone who makes another do wholesome or unwholesome deeds. There is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds. If, Venerable Nāgasena, there was someone who caused you to die, there is no killing of living beings for that person. Venerable Nāgasena, there is no teacher, no preceptor, and no ordination for you.

mil3.1.1:3.6.pli: ‘Nāgasenoti maṃ, mahārāja, sabrahmacārī samudācarantī’ti yaṃ vadesi, katamo ettha nāgaseno?
mil3.1.1:3.6.eng: You say ‘my holy life companions address me as Nāgasena.’ But who here is Nāgasena?

mil3.1.1:3.7.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, bhante, kesā nāgaseno”ti?
mil3.1.1:3.7.eng: Is it, venerable sir, that the hairs of the head are Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.1:3.9.eng: “Are the hairs of the body Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.1:3.40.eng: the brain in the head Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.1:3.52.eng: “Then, venerable sir, are form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness combined Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.1:3.54.eng: “Then, venerable sir, is something other than form, feeling, perception, formations, consciousness combined Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.1:3.56.pli: “Tamahaṃ, bhante, pucchanto pucchanto na passāmi nāgasenaṃ.
mil3.1.1:3.56.eng: “Though, venerable sir, I am asking you repeatedly, I do not see Nāgasena.

mil3.1.1:3.59.pli: “Ko panettha nāgaseno, alikaṃ tvaṃ, bhante, bhāsasi musāvādaṃ, natthi nāgaseno”ti.
mil3.1.1:3.59.eng: “Then, who here is Nāgasena? You speak a falsehood, venerable sir, there is no Nāgasena.”

mil3.1.1:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgaseno milindaṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.1:4.1.eng: Then, Venerable Nāgasena said this to King Milinda,

mil3.1.1:4.2.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, mahārāja, khattiyasukhumālo accantasukhumālo, tassa te, mahārāja, majjhanhikasamayaṃ tattāya bhūmiyā uṇhāya vālikāya kharāya sakkharakathalikāya madditvā pādenāgacchantassa pādā rujjanti, kāyo kilamati, cittaṃ upahaññati, dukkhasahagataṃ kāyaviññāṇaṃ uppajjati, kiṃ nu kho tvaṃ pādenāgatosi, udāhu vāhanenā”ti?
mil3.1.1:4.2.eng: “You are, your majesty, a delicate noble, exceedingly delicate. For one going on foot at midday, on the scorching ground, the hot sand, the rough, sharp pebbles and gravel, the feet are sore, the body is tired, the mind is upset, and body consciousness arises accompanied by suffering. Did you come on foot or rather in a vehicle?”

mil3.1.1:4.3.eng: “I did not come on foot, venerable sir, I came in a chariot.”

mil3.1.1:4.4.pli: “Sace tvaṃ, mahārāja, rathenāgatosi, rathaṃ me ārocehi, kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, īsā ratho”ti?
mil3.1.1:4.4.eng: “If, your majesty, you came in a chariot, tell me about a chariot. Is the carriage pole the chariot?”

mil3.1.1:4.10.eng: “Is the body of the chariot the chariot?”

mil3.1.1:4.20.eng: “Then, your majesty, are the carriage pole, axle, wheels, body of the chariot, flag-staff, yoke, reins, and goad the chariot?”

mil3.1.1:4.22.eng: “Then, your majesty, is something apart from the carriage pole, axle, wheels, body of the chariot, flag-staff, yoke, reins, and goad the chariot?”

mil3.1.1:4.24.pli: “Tamahaṃ, mahārāja, pucchanto pucchanto na passāmi rathaṃ.
mil3.1.1:4.24.eng: “Though, your majesty, I am asking you repeatedly, I do not see a chariot.

mil3.1.1:4.25.eng: Is a chariot only the sound ‘chariot’?”

mil3.1.1:4.27.pli: “Ko panettha ratho, alikaṃ tvaṃ, mahārāja, bhāsasi musāvādaṃ, natthi ratho, tvaṃsi, mahārāja, sakalajambudīpe aggarājā, kassa pana tvaṃ bhāyitvā musāvādaṃ bhāsasi, suṇantu me bhonto pañcasatā yonakā asītisahassā ca bhikkhū, ayaṃ milindo rājā evamāha—
mil3.1.1:4.27.eng: “Then, what here is a chariot? You speak a falsehood, your majesty, there is no chariot. You are, your majesty, a mighty king of all Jambudīpa, who then do you fear that you speak a falsehood. May the venerable five hundred Bactrian Greeks and the eighty thousand bhikkhus hear me. This King Milinda said,

mil3.1.1:4.28.pli: ‘rathenāhaṃ āgatosmī’ti, sace tvaṃ, mahārāja, rathenāgatosi, ‘rathaṃ me ārocehī’ti vutto samāno rathaṃ na sampādeti, kallaṃ nu kho tadabhinanditun”ti.
mil3.1.1:4.28.eng: ‘I came by chariot’. But, on being told, ‘if, your majesty, you came by chariot, declare to me a chariot,’ he is unable to produce a chariot. Is it proper to approve that?”

mil3.1.1:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, pañcasatā yonakā āyasmato nāgasenassa sādhukāraṃ datvā milindaṃ rājānaṃ etadavocuṃ—
mil3.1.1:5.1.eng: When this was said, the five hundred Bactrian Greeks applauded the Venerable Nāgasena and said to King Milinda,

mil3.1.1:5.2.eng: “Now then, your majesty, speak if you can!”

mil3.1.1:6.1.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.1:6.1.eng: Then King Milinda said this to Venerable Nāgasena,

mil3.1.1:6.2.pli: “nāhaṃ, bhante nāgasena, musā bhaṇāmi, īsañca paṭicca akkhañca paṭicca cakkāni ca paṭicca rathapañjarañca paṭicca rathadaṇḍakañca paṭicca ‘ratho’ti saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāro nāmamattaṃ pavattatī”ti.
mil3.1.1:6.2.eng: “I do not speak falsely, venerable sir, because of the carriage pole, the axle, the wheels, the body of the chariot, the flag-staff, there exists a ‘chariot’, as a concept, a designation, a label, an appellation, a mere name.”

mil3.1.1:7.1.eng: “Good, your majesty, you know a chariot.

mil3.1.1:7.2.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, mayhampi kese ca paṭicca lome ca paṭicca …pe… matthake matthaluṅgañca paṭicca rūpañca paṭicca vedanañca paṭicca saññañca paṭicca saṅkhāre ca paṭicca viññāṇañca paṭicca ‘nāgaseno’ti saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāro nāmamattaṃ pavattati, paramatthato panettha puggalo nūpalabbhati.
mil3.1.1:7.2.eng: In the same way, your majesty, because of the head hairs, the body hairs, … brain in the head, and because of form, feeling, perception, volitional formations, consciousness, there exists ‘Nāgasena’, as a concept, a designation, a label, an appellation, a mere name, however in the absolute sense there obtains no person here.

mil3.1.1:7.3.pli: Bhāsitampetaṃ, mahārāja, vajirāya bhikkhuniyā bhagavato sammukhā—
mil3.1.1:7.3.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by Sister Vajirā in the presence of the Blessed One:

mil3.1.1:8.1.eng: ‘Just as, by the coexistence of the various parts,

mil3.1.1:8.3.eng: so, by the existence of the aggregates,

mil3.1.1:8.4.eng: there is a “being” is agreed upon.’”

mil3.1.1:9.1.pli: “Acchariyaṃ, bhante nāgasena, abbhutaṃ, bhante nāgasena, aticitrāni pañhapaṭibhānāni visajjitāni, yadi buddho tiṭṭheyya sādhukāraṃ dadeyya, sādhu sādhu, nāgasena, aticitrāni pañhapaṭibhānāni visajjitānī”ti.
mil3.1.1:9.1.eng: “Wonderful, Venerable Nāgasena! Marvelous, Venerable Nāgasena! Your answers to the questions asked are very brilliant! If the Buddha were here, he would applaud them. Excellent, excellent, Venerable Nāgasena! Your answers to the questions asked are very brilliant!”

mil3.1.10:0.3.eng: 10. Calming as a Distinguishing Characteristic of Faith Question

mil3.1.10:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of faith?”

mil3.1.10:1.3.eng: “Faith, your majesty, has calming as a distinguishing characteristic, and also aspiration.”

mil3.1.10:1.4.eng: “How, venerable sir, is calming a distinguishing characteristic of faith?”

mil3.1.10:1.5.pli: “Saddhā kho, mahārāja, uppajjamānā nīvaraṇe vikkhambheti, vinīvaraṇaṃ cittaṃ hoti acchaṃ vippasannaṃ anāvilaṃ.
mil3.1.10:1.5.eng: “Faith arising suppresses the hindrances, and thus there is a clear, bright, clean mind free of the hindrances.

mil3.1.10:1.6.eng: That’s how, your majesty, calming is a distinguishing characteristic of faith.”

mil3.1.10:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, rājā cakkavattī caturaṅginiyā senāya saddhiṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno parittaṃ udakaṃ tareyya, taṃ udakaṃ hatthīhi ca assehi ca rathehi ca pattīhi ca khubhitaṃ bhaveyya āvilaṃ luḷitaṃ kalalībhūtaṃ.
mil3.1.10:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a wheel-turning king going on a long journey might cross a small body of water, and that water disturbed by the elephants, horses, chariots, and foot-soldiers, would become stirred up, turbid, and muddy;

mil3.1.10:2.3.pli: Uttiṇṇo ca rājā cakkavattī manusse āṇāpeyya ‘pānīyaṃ, bhaṇe, āharatha, pivissāmī’ti, rañño ca udakappasādako maṇi bhaveyya.
mil3.1.10:2.3.eng: and after crossing, the king would command his men, ‘Bring me water, I will drink,’ and the king would possess a water-clearing gem.

mil3.1.10:2.4.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho te manussā rañño cakkavattissa paṭissutvā taṃ udakappasādakaṃ maṇiṃ udake pakkhipeyyuṃ, tasmiṃ udake pakkhittamatte saṅkhasevālapaṇakaṃ vigaccheyya, kaddamo ca sannisīdeyya, acchaṃ bhaveyya udakaṃ vippasannaṃ anāvilaṃ.
mil3.1.10:2.4.eng: The men having given their assent to the wheel-turning king, saying ‘Yes, lord’, would place that water-clearing gem in the water, and after it is placed in that water, the various water plants, slime, and leaves  would disappear, the mud would settle, and the water would become clear, bright, and clean.

mil3.1.10:2.5.pli: Tato rañño cakkavattissa pānīyaṃ upanāmeyyuṃ ‘pivatu, deva, pānīyan’ti.
mil3.1.10:2.5.eng: Then they would bring the water to the wheel-turning king, saying, ‘Drink the water, lord.’

mil3.1.10:3.1.pli: Yathā, mahārāja, udakaṃ, evaṃ cittaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, yathā te manussā, evaṃ yogāvacaro daṭṭhabbo, yathā saṅkhasevālapaṇakaṃ kaddamo ca, evaṃ kilesā daṭṭhabbā.
mil3.1.10:3.1.eng: Just like the water, your majesty, so the mind is to be understood; just like the men, so the spiritual aspirant is to be understood; just like the various water plants, slime, and leaves  and the mud, so the defilements are to be understood;

mil3.1.10:3.2.pli: Yathā udakappasādako maṇi, evaṃ saddhā daṭṭhabbā, yathā udakappasādake maṇimhi udake pakkhittamatte saṅkhasevālapaṇakaṃ vigaccheyya, kaddamo ca sannisīdeyya, acchaṃ bhaveyya udakaṃ vippasannaṃ anāvilaṃ;
mil3.1.10:3.2.eng: just like the water-clearing gem, so faith is to be understood. Just like after the water-clearing gem is placed in the water, the various water plants, slime, and leaves would disappear, and the mud would settle, and the water would become clear, bright, and clean;

mil3.1.10:3.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, saddhā uppajjamānā nīvaraṇe vikkhambheti, vinīvaraṇaṃ cittaṃ hoti acchaṃ vippasannaṃ anāvilaṃ.
mil3.1.10:3.3.eng: in the same way, your majesty, faith arising suppresses the hindrances and the unobstructed mind is clear, bright, and clean.

mil3.1.10:3.4.eng: And in this way, your majesty, calming is a distinguishing characteristic of faith.”

mil3.1.10:5.1.eng: Calming as a Distinguishing Characteristic of Faith Question tenth

mil3.1.11:0.3.eng: 11. Aspiration as a Distinguishing Characteristic of Faith Question

mil3.1.11:1.1.eng: “How, venerable sir, is aspiration a distinguishing characteristic of faith?”

mil3.1.11:1.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, yogāvacaro aññesaṃ cittaṃ vimuttaṃ passitvā sotāpattiphale vā sakadāgāmiphale vā anāgāmiphale vā arahatte vā sampakkhandati yogaṃ karoti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
mil3.1.11:1.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a spiritual aspirant, having seen the liberated mind of others, aspires to the fruit of stream entry, or to the fruit of once-returning, or to the fruit of non-returning, or to the fruit of arahantship, and practices for the attainment of the unattained, for the achievement of the unachieved, and for the realisation of the unrealised.

mil3.1.11:1.3.eng: Thus, your majesty, is aspiration a distinguishing characteristic of faith.”

mil3.1.11:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, uparipabbate mahāmegho abhippavasseyya, taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūretvā nadiṃ paripūreyya, sā ubhato kūlāni saṃvissandantī gaccheyya, atha mahājanakāyo āgantvā tassā nadiyā uttānataṃ vā gambhīrataṃ vā ajānanto bhīto vitthato tīre tiṭṭheyya, athaññataro puriso āgantvā attano thāmañca balañca sampassanto gāḷhaṃ kacchaṃ bandhitvā pakkhanditvā tareyya, taṃ tiṇṇaṃ passitvā mahājanakāyopi tareyya;
mil3.1.11:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a great cloud might pour down rain on the top of a mountain, and that water flowing down according to the slope, having filled the gullies, clefts, and rivulets on the mountain, would fill the river which would proceed along overflowing both banks. And then a great crowd of people having gone to that river, not knowing how shallow or deep it is, would stand frightened and spread out on the bank, and then a certain man might come, and considering his own power and strength, would bind tightly his loincloth and cross over. The great crowd of people having seen him cross would cross over also.

mil3.1.11:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro aññesaṃ cittaṃ vimuttaṃ passitvā sotāpattiphale vā sakadāgāmiphale vā anāgāmiphale vā arahatte vā sampakkhandati yogaṃ karoti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
mil3.1.11:2.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, a spiritual aspirant, having seen the liberated mind of others, aspires to the fruit of stream entry, or to the fruit of once-returning, or to the fruit of non-returning, or to the fruit of arahantship, and practices for the attainment of the unattained, for the achievement of the unachieved, and for the realisation of the unrealised.

mil3.1.11:2.4.eng: In the same way, your majesty, is aspiration a distinguishing characteristic of faith.

mil3.1.11:2.5.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One in the excellent Saṃyutta Nikāya:

mil3.1.11:5.1.eng: Aspiration as a Distinguishing Characteristic of Faith Question eleventh

mil3.1.12:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of exertion?”

mil3.1.12:1.3.pli: “Upatthambhanalakkhaṇaṃ, mahārāja, vīriyaṃ, vīriyūpatthambhitā sabbe kusalā dhammā na parihāyantī”ti.
mil3.1.12:1.3.eng: “Exertion, your majesty, has supporting as a distinguishing characteristic, and no wholesome mental states supported by exertion decline.”

mil3.1.12:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, puriso gehe patante aññena dārunā upatthambheyya, upatthambhitaṃ santaṃ evaṃ taṃ gehaṃ na pateyya;
mil3.1.12:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a man, when his house is falling down, might support it with additional wood, so that, being thus supported, that house would not fall down.

mil3.1.12:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, upatthambhanalakkhaṇaṃ vīriyaṃ, vīriyūpatthambhitā sabbe kusalā dhammā na parihāyantī”ti.
mil3.1.12:2.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, exertion has supporting as a distinguishing characteristic, and no wholesome mental states supported by exertion decline.”

mil3.1.12:3.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, parittakaṃ senaṃ mahatī senā bhañjeyya, tato rājā aññamaññaṃ anussāreyya anupeseyya attano parittakāya senāya balaṃ anupadaṃ dadeyya, tāya saddhiṃ parittakā senā mahatiṃ senaṃ bhañjeyya;
mil3.1.12:3.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a large army might destroy a small army, then the king would recall another and send for them in order to give additional strength to his own small army, and with that, the small army would destroy the large army.

mil3.1.12:3.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, upatthambhanalakkhaṇaṃ vīriyaṃ, vīriyūpatthambhitā sabbe kusalā dhammā na parihāyanti.
mil3.1.12:3.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, exertion has supporting as a distinguishing characteristic, and no wholesome mental states supported by exertion decline.

mil3.1.12:3.4.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.1.12:3.5.pli: ‘vīriyavā kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti.
mil3.1.12:3.5.eng: ‘A noble disciple endowed with exertion abandons the unwholesome, develops the wholesome;

mil3.1.12:3.6.eng: Abandons the blameworthy, develops the blameless,

mil3.1.12:5.1.eng: Distinguishing Characteristic of Exertion Question twelfth

mil3.1.13:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of mindfulness?”

mil3.1.13:1.3.eng: “Mindfulness, your majesty, has not wavering as a distinguishing characteristic, and also taking up.”

mil3.1.13:1.4.eng: “How, venerable sir, does mindfulness have not wavering as a distinguishing characteristic?”

mil3.1.13:1.5.pli: “Sati, mahārāja, uppajjamānā kusalākusalasāvajjānavajjahīnappaṇītakaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgadhamme apilāpeti ‘ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, ime cattāro sammappadhānā, ime cattāro iddhipādā, imāni pañcindriyāni, imāni pañca balāni, ime satta bojjhaṅgā, ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, ayaṃ samatho, ayaṃ vipassanā, ayaṃ vijjā, ayaṃ vimuttī’ti.
mil3.1.13:1.5.eng: “Mindfulness arising, your majesty, does not waver concerning things that are wholesome and unwholesome, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, dark and light, or evenly mixed, thinking ‘these are the four establishments of mindfulness, these the four right strivings, these the four bases for psychic power, these the five faculties, these the five powers, these the seven factors of enlightenment, this the noble eightfold path, this serenity, this insight, this knowledge, this liberation’.

mil3.1.13:1.6.pli: Tato yogāvacaro sevitabbe dhamme sevati, asevitabbe dhamme na sevati.
mil3.1.13:1.6.eng: Then, the spiritual aspirant engages in the things that should be engaged in, and does not engage in the things that should not be engaged in;

mil3.1.13:1.7.pli: Bhajitabbe dhamme bhajati abhajitabbe dhamme na bhajati.
mil3.1.13:1.7.eng: associates with things that should be associated with, and does not associate with things that should not be associated with.

mil3.1.13:1.8.eng: Thus, your majesty, does mindfulness have not wavering as a distinguishing characteristic.”

mil3.1.13:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, rañño cakkavattissa bhaṇḍāgāriko rājānaṃ cakkavattiṃ sāyaṃ pātaṃ yasaṃ sarāpeti ‘ettakā, deva, te hatthī, ettakā assā, ettakā rathā, ettakā pattī, ettakaṃ hiraññaṃ, ettakaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ, ettakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ, taṃ devo saratū’ti rañño sāpateyyaṃ apilāpeti;
mil3.1.13:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a wheel-turning king’s storekeeper reminds that king by night and day of his fame, saying, ‘So many elephants are yours, sire, so many horses, so many chariots, so many foot-soldiers, so much gold, so many gold objects, so much wealth, let his majesty remember it’, and he does not waver concerning the king’s wealth.

mil3.1.13:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, sati uppajjamānā kusalākusalasāvajjānavajjahīnappaṇītakaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgadhamme apilāpeti ‘ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, ime cattāro sammappadhānā, ime cattāro iddhipādā, imāni pañcindriyāni, imāni pañca balāni, ime satta bojjhaṅgā, ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, ayaṃ samatho, ayaṃ vipassanā, ayaṃ vijjā, ayaṃ vimuttī’ti.
mil3.1.13:2.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, mindfulness arising does not waver concerning things that are wholesome and unwholesome, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, dark and light, or evenly mixed, thinking ‘these are the four establishments of mindfulness, these the four right strivings, these the four bases for psychic power, these the five faculties, these the five powers, these the seven factors of enlightenment, this the noble eightfold path, this serenity, this insight, this knowledge, this liberation’.

mil3.1.13:2.4.pli: Tato yogāvacaro sevitabbe dhamme sevati, asevitabbe dhamme na sevati.
mil3.1.13:2.4.eng: Then, the spiritual aspirant engages in the things that should be engaged in, and does not engage in the things that should not be engaged in;

mil3.1.13:2.5.pli: Bhajitabbe dhamme bhajati, abhajitabbe dhamme na bhajati.
mil3.1.13:2.5.eng: associates with things that should be associated with, and does not associate with things that should not be associated with.

mil3.1.13:2.6.eng: Thus, your majesty, does mindfulness have not wavering as a distinguishing characteristic.”

mil3.1.13:3.1.eng: “How, venerable sir, does mindfulness have taking up as a distinguishing characteristic?”

mil3.1.13:3.2.pli: “Sati, mahārāja, uppajjamānā hitāhitānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo samanveti ‘ime dhammā hitā, ime dhammā ahitā.
mil3.1.13:3.2.eng: “Mindfulness arising, your majesty, examines the courses of mental states that are beneficial or non-beneficial, thinking ‘these mental states are beneficial, these are non-beneficial;

mil3.1.13:3.3.pli: Ime dhammā upakārā, ime dhammā anupakārā’ti.
mil3.1.13:3.3.eng: these mental states are supportive, these are not supportive.’

mil3.1.13:3.4.pli: Tato yogāvacaro ahite dhamme apanudeti, hite dhamme upaggaṇhāti.
mil3.1.13:3.4.eng: Then, the spiritual aspirant dispels non-beneficial mental states and takes up beneficial mental states;

mil3.1.13:3.5.pli: Anupakāre dhamme apanudeti, upakāre dhamme upaggaṇhāti.
mil3.1.13:3.5.eng: dispels non-supportive mental states and takes up supportive ones.

mil3.1.13:3.6.eng: Thus, your majesty, does mindfulness have taking up as a distinguishing characteristic.”

mil3.1.13:4.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, rañño cakkavattissa pariṇāyakaratanaṃ rañño hitāhite jānāti ‘ime rañño hitā, ime ahitā.
mil3.1.13:4.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a wheel-turning king’s treasured adviser knows what is beneficial and non-beneficial for the king, thinking ‘these are beneficial for the king, these are non-beneficial;

mil3.1.13:4.3.eng: these are supportive, these are not supportive.’

mil3.1.13:4.4.eng: Then, he dispels the non-beneficial and takes up the beneficial;

mil3.1.13:4.5.eng: dispels the non-supportive and takes up the supportive.

mil3.1.13:4.6.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, sati uppajjamānā hitāhitānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo samanveti ‘ime dhammā hitā, ime dhammā ahitā.
mil3.1.13:4.6.eng: In the same way, your majesty, mindfulness arising examines mental states that are beneficial or non-beneficial, thinking ‘these mental states are beneficial, these are non-beneficial;

mil3.1.13:4.7.pli: Ime dhammā upakārā, ime dhammā anupakārā’ti.
mil3.1.13:4.7.eng: these mental states are supportive, these are not supportive.’

mil3.1.13:4.8.pli: Tato yogāvacaro ahite dhamme apanudeti, hite dhamme upaggaṇhāti.
mil3.1.13:4.8.eng: Then, the spiritual aspirant dispels non-beneficial mental states and takes up beneficial mental states;

mil3.1.13:4.9.pli: Anupakāre dhamme apanudeti, upakāre damme upaggaṇhāti.
mil3.1.13:4.9.eng: dispels non-supportive mental states and takes up supportive ones.

mil3.1.13:4.10.eng: Thus, your majesty, does mindfulness have taking up as a distinguishing characteristic.

mil3.1.13:4.11.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.1.13:4.12.eng: ‘I say, bhikkhus, that mindfulness is always useful.’”

mil3.1.13:6.1.eng: Distinguishing Characteristic of Mindfulness Question thirteenth

mil3.1.14:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of concentration?”

mil3.1.14:1.3.pli: “Pamukhalakkhaṇo, mahārāja, samādhi, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te samādhipamukhā honti samādhininnā samādhipoṇā samādhipabbhārā”ti.
mil3.1.14:1.3.eng: “Concentration, your majesty, has being the foremost as a distinguishing characteristic, whatever wholesome mental states there are all these have concentration as the foremost, they lean towards concentration, slope towards concentration, and incline towards concentration.”

mil3.1.14:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kūṭāgārassa yā kāci gopānasiyo, sabbā tā kūṭaṅgamā honti kūṭaninnā kūṭasamosaraṇā, kūṭaṃ tāsaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
mil3.1.14:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, whatever rafters there are in a house with a ridge pole, all the rafters go to that ridge pole, lean towards it, converge at it, and it is considered to be the chief of them.

mil3.1.14:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te samādhipamukhā honti samādhininnā samādhipoṇā samādhipabbhārā”ti.
mil3.1.14:2.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, whatever wholesome mental states there are all these have concentration as the foremost, they lean towards concentration, slope towards concentration, and incline towards concentration.”

mil3.1.14:3.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, koci rājā caturaṅginiyā senāya saddhiṃ saṅgāmaṃ otareyya, sabbāva senā hatthī ca assā ca rathā ca pattī ca tappamukhā bhaveyyuṃ tanninnā tappoṇā tappabbhārā taṃyeva anupariyāyeyyuṃ;
mil3.1.14:3.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, whatever king with his four-factored army would go down into battle, all the army – the elephants, horses, chariots, and foot-soldiers – would have him as the foremost, lean towards him, slope towards him, and incline towards him, and would gather around him.

mil3.1.14:3.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te samādhipamukhā honti samādhininnā samādhipoṇā samādhipabbhārā.
mil3.1.14:3.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, whatever wholesome mental states there are all these have concentration as the foremost, they lean towards concentration, slope towards concentration, and incline towards concentration.

mil3.1.14:3.4.eng: Thus, your majesty, concentration has being the foremost as a distinguishing characteristic.

mil3.1.14:3.5.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.1.14:3.6.pli: ‘samādhiṃ, bhikkhave, bhāvetha, samāhito, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī’”ti.
mil3.1.14:3.6.eng: ‘Develop concentration, bhikkhus. A concentrated bhikkhu knows things as they really are.’”
